Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical Investigations in Classical and Quantum Gravity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Several fundamental issues in gravitational physics will be investigated. These are related to the physics of the very early universe, unification of Einstein's general relativity and quantum physics, and the final stages of black hole formation and mergers. Although cosmology has witnessed spectacular progress over the past decade, fundamental problems remain. Through a judicious unification of general relativity with quantum physics, over the last five years, our team has provided a detailed theoretical paradigm as to what "really" occurred near the big bang. Detailed consequences of this "physics beyond Einstein", including potentially observable effects, will be analyzed in detail using a combination of analytical and numerical techniques. Black hole formation and collisions are violent events where the full non-linearity general relativity is important. State of the art mathematical tools will be used to describe how these black holes settle down to their final equilibrium.

This research will continue to have an impact on a number of disciplines in fundamental science (general relativity, cosmology, and quantum physics), areas of pure and applied mathematics (functional analysis, geometry and computational science) and philosophy of science. As in the past, Ph.D. students and post-doctoral scholars will trained in these broad areas of knowledge. Because the public is fascinated by the fundamental questions that will be addressed, there will also be a significant contribution to outreach through public lectures, articles and reports in semi-popular magazines, electronic media including scientific videos and YouTube clips and an active collaboration with artists interested in representations of the cutting edge scientific ideas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research completed under this contract falls in two broad categories: (1) Study of the strong-field sector of Einstein's theory of general relativity, especially black holes and gravitational waves; and (2) The interface of general relativity with quantum physics. A large number of projects were completed by the PI, 5 post-docs, 2 graduate students and 3 long-term visitors. Results were reported in refereed journal articles, select research volumes, and numerous national and international conferences and workshops. This brief summary provides a few illustrative highlights.

In the first category, we studied how a black hole approaches its final equilibrium state. When it first forms, the gravitational field in the vicinity of the black hole and the geometry of its surface are quite complicated but when it `settles down' they are both quite simple. How do the complications get ironed out? To analyze this process we defined `horizon multipole moments', attributes that capture the complexities of the geometry of the surface of the black hole, and used Einstein's equations to gain control on the process by which the black hole get rid of these messy complications. This analysis will be useful for numerical simulations and could lead to the discovery of universal features of non-linear Einstein's equations that have remained hidden so far. The multipoles we defined also serve as detailed mathematical tools to test the ideas that Hawking and Perry have recently proposed to address the issue of information loss. Another set of problems addressed the longstanding issue of incorporating the observed, positive cosmological constant in the theory of gravitational waves. This theory was developed almost 50 years ago and is heavily used in much of gravitational wave physics today, including numerical simulations. At the time it was developed, it was widely believed that the cosmological constant in our universe is zero. Over the past two decades observations have established that the universe is undergoing an accelerated expansion that is best modeled by a positive cosmological constant. Given that we are now on the threshold of the new era of gravitational wave astronomy, it is important for the theoretical foundations of the subject to incorporate this fact in a systematic fashion. However, the problem has been open for some 50 years because the necessary generalization of the standard theory raises a host of unforeseen difficulties. Our series of papers in this area has already addressed several of these issues and ongoing research will address the rest over the next year.

The second category contained a large variety of problems in the framework of `Loop Quantum Gravity, a leading approach aimed at unifying general relativity and quantum physics. The most important among them is the application of this approach to the physics of the very early universe.  Thanks to the spectacular advances on the observational front over the past two decades, we can now begin to address fundamental questions such as: What really happened at the big bang? Can one carry out concrete calculations to shed light on this fascinating epoch? Can we test these theories in observations? We have successfully extended the standard cosmological model with inflation, back in time, over 12 orders of magnitude of matter density and shown that the big bang is an artifact of pushing general relativity beyond its domain of applicability. In Loop Quantum Cosmology, the big bang is replaced by a big bounce where quantum physics remains under full mathematical control.
